examples.title: Countability of the Rationals
examples.statement: Prove that the set $\mathbb{Q}$ of all rational numbers is countable.

steps.title: Strategy
steps.content: We will show that $\mathbb{Q}^+$ (positive rationals) is countable, then extend to all of $\mathbb{Q}$.

steps.title: Arrange positive rationals in a grid
steps.content:
Write all positive rationals $p/q$ (in lowest terms) in a grid where row $q$ contains all fractions with denominator $q$:

$1/1, 2/1, 3/1, \ldots$
$1/2, 3/2, 5/2, \ldots$
$1/3, 2/3, 4/3, \ldots$

steps.title: Diagonal enumeration
steps.content:
Enumerate by diagonals: $1/1, 2/1, 1/2, 3/1, 1/3, 4/1, 3/2, 2/3, 1/4, \ldots$

This gives a bijection $f: \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{Q}^+$.

steps.title: Extend to all rationals
steps.content: $\mathbb{Q} = \{0\} \cup \mathbb{Q}^+ \cup \mathbb{Q}^-$. Since $\mathbb{Q}^- \cong \mathbb{Q}^+$ and a countable union of countable sets is countable, $\mathbb{Q}$ is countable.

solution.conclusion: The rationals are countable. This is remarkable because $\mathbb{Q}$ is dense in $\mathbb{R}$, yet has the same cardinality as $\mathbb{N}$.

exercises.statement: Prove that the empty set is a subset of every set.

steps.title: Definition of subset
steps.content: $A \subseteq B$ means: for all $x$, if $x \in A$ then $x \in B$.

steps.title: Vacuous truth
steps.content: For $A = \emptyset$: the statement "if $x \in \emptyset$ then $x \in B$" is vacuously true because there is no $x \in \emptyset$.

steps.title: Logical form
steps.content: The implication $P \Rightarrow Q$ is true whenever $P$ is false. Since "$x \in \emptyset$" is always false, the implication holds for all $x$.

solution.conclusion: $\emptyset \subseteq B$ for every set $B$. This is why $\emptyset$ is called the "empty set" - it has no elements to violate any subset condition.

exercises.statement: A complex number $z$ is said to be algebraic if there are integers $a_0, \ldots, a_n$, not all zero, such that $a_0 z^n + a_1 z^{n-1} + \cdots + a_{n-1} z + a_n = 0$. Prove that the set of all algebraic numbers is countable.

steps.title: Count polynomials of fixed degree and height
steps.content: For each $n \geq 1$, let $P_n$ be the set of polynomials of degree $n$ with integer coefficients. Define the height $h = |a_0| + |a_1| + \cdots + |a_n|$.

steps.title: Finite polynomials per height
steps.content: For fixed $n$ and $h$, there are only finitely many polynomials (since coefficients are bounded). Each polynomial has at most $n$ roots.

steps.title: Countable union
steps.content: The algebraic numbers are a countable union (over $n$ and $h$) of finite sets of roots. A countable union of finite sets is countable.

solution.conclusion: The set of algebraic numbers is countable. Combined with the uncountability of $\mathbb{R}$, this proves the existence of transcendental numbers (like $e$ and $\pi$).

exercises.statement: Prove that there exist real numbers which are not algebraic.

steps.title: Use cardinality
steps.content: We proved that algebraic numbers are countable, but $\mathbb{R}$ is uncountable (by Cantor's diagonal argument).

steps.title: Conclude existence
steps.content: If all real numbers were algebraic, then $\mathbb{R}$ would be countable (as a subset of a countable set). This contradicts the uncountability of $\mathbb{R}$.

solution.conclusion: There exist real numbers that are not algebraic. Such numbers are called transcendental. In fact, "most" real numbers are transcendental in the sense that the algebraic numbers have measure zero.

exercises.statement: Is the set of all irrational real numbers countable?

steps.title: Assume countable
steps.content: Suppose the irrationals $\mathbb{R} \setminus \mathbb{Q}$ were countable.

steps.title: Apply union
steps.content: Then $\mathbb{R} = \mathbb{Q} \cup (\mathbb{R} \setminus \mathbb{Q})$ would be a union of two countable sets, hence countable.

steps.title: Contradiction
steps.content: But $\mathbb{R}$ is uncountable (Cantor's theorem). Contradiction.

solution.conclusion: The set of irrational numbers is uncountable. In fact, removing any countable set from $\mathbb{R}$ leaves an uncountable set.

exercises.statement: Let $E'$ denote the set of all limit points of a set $E$. Prove that $E'$ is closed.

steps.title: Show (E')' ⊆ E'
steps.content: Let $x$ be a limit point of $E'$. We need to show $x \in E'$, i.e., $x$ is a limit point of $E$.

steps.title: Use neighborhood definition
steps.content: Let $N$ be any neighborhood of $x$. Since $x$ is a limit point of $E'$, there exists $y \in E' \cap N$ with $y \neq x$.

steps.title: Find point of E
steps.content: Since $y \in E'$ and $N$ is open, there exists a neighborhood $M \subseteq N$ of $y$. Since $y$ is a limit point of $E$, there exists $z \in E \cap M$ with $z \neq y$.

steps.title: Conclude
steps.content: Thus $z \in E \cap N$ and we can ensure $z \neq x$ by choosing $M$ small enough. This shows $x$ is a limit point of $E$.

solution.conclusion: $E'$ is closed because it contains all its limit points: $(E')' \subseteq E'$.

exercises.statement: Let $A$ and $B$ be separated subsets of some $\mathbb{R}^k$, suppose $\mathbf{a} \in A$, $\mathbf{b} \in B$, and define $\mathbf{p}(t) = (1-t)\mathbf{a} + t\mathbf{b}$ for $t \in [0,1]$. Put $A_0 = \mathbf{p}^{-1}(A)$ and $B_0 = \mathbf{p}^{-1}(B)$. Prove that $A_0$ and $B_0$ are separated subsets of $[0,1]$.

steps.title: Definitions
steps.content: $A_0 = \{t \in [0,1] : \mathbf{p}(t) \in A\}$ and $B_0 = \{t \in [0,1] : \mathbf{p}(t) \in B\}$.

steps.title: Show A₀ ∩ B̄₀ = ∅
steps.content:
Suppose $t \in A_0 \cap \overline{B_0}$. Then $\mathbf{p}(t) \in A$ and $t$ is in the closure of $B_0$.

If $t \in B_0$, then $\mathbf{p}(t) \in A \cap B = \emptyset$, contradiction.

If $t$ is a limit point of $B_0$, then $\mathbf{p}(t)$ is a limit point of $B$ (by continuity of $\mathbf{p}$). So $\mathbf{p}(t) \in A \cap \overline{B} = \emptyset$, contradiction.

steps.title: Similarly for Ā₀ ∩ B₀
steps.content: By symmetry, $\overline{A_0} \cap B_0 = \emptyset$.

solution.conclusion: $A_0$ and $B_0$ are separated subsets of $[0,1]$, with $0 \in A_0$ and $1 \in B_0$.

examples.title: Heine-Borel Theorem
examples.statement: Prove that a subset of $\mathbb{R}^k$ is compact if and only if it is closed and bounded.

steps.title: Compact ⟹ closed
steps.content: Let $K$ be compact. If $p \notin K$, for each $q \in K$ choose disjoint neighborhoods $V_q$ of $p$ and $W_q$ of $q$. The $W_q$ cover $K$, so finitely many $W_{q_1}, \ldots, W_{q_n}$ cover $K$. Then $V = V_{q_1} \cap \cdots \cap V_{q_n}$ is a neighborhood of $p$ disjoint from $K$. So $K^c$ is open.

steps.title: Compact ⟹ bounded
steps.content: The open balls $B(0, n)$ for $n \in \mathbb{N}$ cover $K$. By compactness, finitely many suffice, so $K \subseteq B(0, N)$ for some $N$.

steps.title: Closed and bounded ⟹ compact
steps.content: If $K$ is closed and bounded, then $K \subseteq [-M, M]^k$ for some $M$. The $k$-cell $[-M, M]^k$ is compact (by the nested intervals theorem). A closed subset of a compact set is compact.

solution.conclusion: In $\mathbb{R}^k$, compact = closed + bounded. This fails in general metric spaces.

exercises.statement: Prove that every infinite subset of a compact set has a limit point in $K$.

steps.title: Contrapositive
steps.content: Suppose $E \subseteq K$ is infinite and has no limit point in $K$. We derive a contradiction.

steps.title: Construct an open cover
steps.content: For each $q \in K$, since $q$ is not a limit point of $E$, there is a neighborhood $V_q$ containing at most one point of $E$ (namely $q$ itself if $q \in E$).

steps.title: Apply compactness
steps.content: The $V_q$ cover $K$. By compactness, finitely many $V_{q_1}, \ldots, V_{q_n}$ cover $K$. But then $E \subseteq K \subseteq V_{q_1} \cup \cdots \cup V_{q_n}$ contains at most $n$ points.

steps.title: Contradiction
steps.content: This contradicts $E$ being infinite.

solution.conclusion: Every infinite subset of a compact set has a limit point in the compact set. This is the Bolzano-Weierstrass property.

exercises.statement: If $\{K_\alpha\}$ is a collection of compact subsets of a metric space $X$ such that the intersection of every finite subcollection is nonempty, prove that $\bigcap K_\alpha$ is nonempty.

steps.title: Reformulate
steps.content: Fix $K_1$. We need to show $K_1 \cap \bigcap_{\alpha} K_\alpha \neq \emptyset$.

steps.title: Define closed sets
steps.content: Let $G_\alpha = K_1 \cap K_\alpha$. Each $G_\alpha$ is closed in $K_1$ (intersection of closed sets). We need $\bigcap G_\alpha \neq \emptyset$.

steps.title: Finite intersection property
steps.content: Any finite intersection $G_{\alpha_1} \cap \cdots \cap G_{\alpha_n} = K_1 \cap K_{\alpha_1} \cap \cdots \cap K_{\alpha_n} \neq \emptyset$ by hypothesis.

steps.title: Apply compactness
steps.content: If $\bigcap G_\alpha = \emptyset$, then $\{K_1 \setminus G_\alpha\}$ is an open cover of $K_1$. By compactness, finitely many cover $K_1$, so some finite intersection of $G_\alpha$'s is empty. Contradiction.

solution.conclusion: A collection of compact sets with the finite intersection property has nonempty intersection. This is equivalent to compactness.

exercises.statement: Prove that a set $E \subseteq \mathbb{R}^1$ is connected if and only if it has the following property: If $x \in E$, $y \in E$, and $x < z < y$, then $z \in E$.

steps.title: ⟹ direction
steps.content: Suppose $E$ is connected and $x, y \in E$ with $x < z < y$ but $z \notin E$. Then $A = E \cap (-\infty, z)$ and $B = E \cap (z, \infty)$ are separated (disjoint open sets in the subspace topology), nonempty ($x \in A$, $y \in B$), and $E = A \cup B$. This contradicts connectedness.

steps.title: ⟸ direction
steps.content:
Suppose $E$ has the intermediate property. If $E = A \cup B$ with $A, B$ separated and nonempty, pick $a \in A$, $b \in B$, say $a < b$.

Let $c = \sup(A \cap [a, b])$. Then $a \leq c \leq b$.

steps.title: Show c leads to contradiction
steps.content:
If $c \in A$: Since $A$ is open in $E$, some interval $(c-\epsilon, c+\epsilon) \cap E \subseteq A$. By the intermediate property, $[a, c+\epsilon/2] \cap E \subseteq E$, so there's an element of $A$ greater than $c$. Contradiction.

If $c \in B$: Similarly, there's an upper bound for $A \cap [a,b]$ less than $c$. Contradiction.

If $c \notin E$: Then $a < c < b$ with $a, b \in E$ but $c \notin E$, contradicting the intermediate property.

solution.conclusion: A subset of $\mathbb{R}$ is connected iff it is an interval (possibly unbounded, possibly a single point).
